content.question: Human and other animal waste can result in water and air pollution.(a) Eutrophication of waterways is a potential environmental problem that can result from concentrated animal feeding operations (<math alttext="C A F Os" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>CAFOs</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>).i. Describe how eutrophication negatively affects waterways.

frqParts.text: Human and other animal waste can result in water and air pollution.(a) Eutrophication of waterways is a potential environmental problem that can result from concentrated animal feeding operations (<math alttext="C A F Os" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>CAFOs</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>).i. Describe how eutrophication negatively affects waterways.
ii. Propose a realistic solution to prevent eutrophication of waterways near <math alttext="C A F Os" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>CAFOs</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>.
iii. Justify the solution you described in (a)(ii) with an additional environmental benefit.

(b) Organic materials (such as food scraps and yard waste) in landfills can decompose and produce landfill gas (<math alttext="L F G"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>LFG</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>) over time. About <math alttext="50%"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>50%</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> of <math alttext="L F G"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>LFG</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> is methane, a greenhouse gas with a global warming potential <math alttext="25"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>25</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> times higher than that of carbon dioxide over a <math alttext="100"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>100</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>-year period. <math alttext="L F G"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>LFG</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> can be collected and burned to produce electricity.i. Explain a process during which <math alttext="L F G"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>LFG</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> is burned to produce electricity.

ii. The Puente Hills Landfill in California contains about <math alttext="123"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>123</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> million tons of landfill waste and burns <math alttext="L F G"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>LFG</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> to produce electricity. In a typical landfill, one million tons of landfill waste emits approximately <math alttext="432,000"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>432,000</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> cubic feet of <math alttext="L F G"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>LFG</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> per day. Calculate how much <math alttext="L F G"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>LFG</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> is emitted at the Puente Hills Landfill per year.

iii. Burning <math alttext="L F G"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>LFG</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> for electricity produces the additional benefit of preventing methane from entering the atmosphere. Calculate how much methane is prevented from entering the atmosphere by burning <math alttext="L F G"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>LFG</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> to produce electricity at the Puente Hills Landfill over a <math alttext="10"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>10</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>-year period.

iv. All of the landfills in the United States that burn <math alttext="L F G"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>LFG</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> to produce electricity produce a total of about <math alttext="15"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>15</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> billion kilowatt-hours (<math alttext="k W h"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>kWh</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>) of electricity per year. The average house in the United States uses about <math alttext="30.3 kilowatt hours"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>30.3 kWh</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> of electricity per day. Calculate how many households can have their total electricity needs provided by these landfills.

skill.text: Skill 1.A: Describe environmental concepts and processes.
